ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think my favorite and least favorite parts of the course came from the fact that it was applied. This let us come away with a lot of very applicable insights, but also meant that the timing of getting feedback and information from the stakeholders -- things really outside the control of the professor and TAs -- could throw projects and the class for a loop.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Focusing on one project throughout the semester to really get involved in it and get the most out of the experience.
Working with the architecture students; having a clear case study for the material; extensive class feedback on project iterations.

This is a very valuable course. The interaction of architecture and FES students in this course is unlike anything offered on campus and is a tremendous asset to each school and their students. More opportunities of this kind should be offered. The topic of the course and the instructor's work really are at the leading edge of innovation in ecology and design. The instructor has a significant amount of real-world experience and examples to bring to course discussions.

This course was a great learning opportunity. Working on a real world project was a great way to put into practice the ideas and theory we discussed in class. The mix of architecture and forestry students made discussions truly interdisciplinary and I think students from both schools learned from one another.
Put designers and ecologist together to deal with practical project
Working with architects, engaging in dialogues with a completely different mode of thinking.
Chance to learn from architecture students, and to get an overview of the state of designed experiments.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lectures could become a bit more interactive (hands on) instead of focusing heavily on reading discussions
Time-management for the class was sometimes disorganized.

At times the class seemed a bit disorganized and it was unclear what was expected for particular assignments. Some of this may be the nature of the course and the challenge of ecologists and designers learning each others language and perspectives. It all came together well in the end, but ways to find clarity along the way would be beneficial.

I think engaging the stakeholders much, much, earlier -- before a project is even conceptualized -- would have saved us so much time, and enabled us to hone in on a good project earlier in the course, giving us more time to refine and locate it. Clearer expectations, in general, would be helpful when you have students from so many different perspectives coming together.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no discussion or lab outside of lecture

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course is helpful for my future master thesis and help me get better understanding of stockholder's role in the whole project.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted a course that would focus on one project that involved both design and ecology and this sounded like the perfect class for my situation.
Based on my personal interests in landscape architecture
To become more familiar with urban conservation issues and challenges.
Seemed like a great way to get a sense of how architecture and ecology can inform each other in practice.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes!
Yes. I got the general idea of how design experiment works.
Yes, very much so.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: The advantages were learning from one another as some of us came from different academic backgrounds. However, that also sometimes got in the way of communicating our opinions on the design aspect of the project
Great practice communicating with non-scientists and trying to think creatively/design-orientedly about environmental problems.
I think it is great practice to work in a group. I learned a lot from my group members, particularly the chance to work with a student in the architecture school (I am in forestry).
I can get the feedback from people who have different background with me and learn a lot from them.
Very collaborative group work emerged. Challenge was dividing the graphic work and text work.

Great to learn from others' perspectives and expertise; wish we had found a way to delve into points of different perspectives and to forge a model for how to integrate the design and ecological elements of our proposal early on in the course.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Be open to extensive group work and start becoming very familiar with the study site early in the semester.
Ask lots of questions. Make the most of the unique opportunity to have discussions and work with people from a different discipline.
highly recommended
Be sure to mix with architectural students, if you are FES students.
Be prepared to be very engaged in the class to get out of it what you want. The class may at times be disorganized, but there is really valuable material to learn and a great environment to do it in.
Really interesting experience; be sure to reach out to the stakeholders or other fellows as early as you can, so you don't invest time and energy into projects that won't be workable.
